;新加坡亿万富翁酒店经营者 Ong Beng Seng，他是新加坡主办城市的幕后推手其公司周五表示，该公司已收到与涉及交通部长 S. Iswaran 的腐败调查有关的“逮捕通知”。

;

;在向新加坡交易所发出的通知中，周五上午，酒店地产有限公司表示，Ong 已通知他，新加坡腐败行为调查局 (CPIB) 指示他提供有关他与 Iswaran 互动的更多信息。

;

;“尚未提出任何指控反对王先生。他将于 2023 年 7 月 14 日开始旅行，返回新加坡后将向 CPIB 上交护照。他已收到逮捕通知，并已缴纳 10 万新元的保释金，”该公司声明称。它没有提供他目前行踪的详细信息。

;

;“Ong先生正在与CPIB充分合作，并已提供了所要求的信息。由于这是一个持续的问题，他目前无法提供进一步的细节。他已承诺，如果有后续重大进展，将向董事会提供最新情况。”

;

;执政的人民行动党因腐败调查而陷入困境，新加坡副总理黄承诺透明度

;

;总理李显龙周三指示长期执政的人民行动党的坚定支持者伊斯瓦兰休假，等待 CPIB 的调查。

;

;CPIB 表示无法透露有关对该部长调查的更多细节– 近四十年来该国最引人注目的反腐败调查。

;

;伊斯瓦兰是一名前高级公务员，因在帮助新加坡获得主办一站比赛的权利方面发挥了重要作用而受到广泛赞誉。一级方程式夜间比赛从 2008 年开始。

;

;新加坡赛事由 Ong 部分拥有，其 HPL 对四季酒店和科莫酒店等著名酒店品牌拥有权益。

;

;新加坡标志性的一级方程式夜间赛事在 2020 年和 2021 年因新冠肺炎疫情中断了两年，但去年又重新迎来了创纪录的观众人数，组织者已将在该国举办比赛的合同续签至 2028 年。

;

; Fri, 14 Jul 2023 08:50:02 +0800 Chinese e-commerce giant JD.com unveils own large language model, ChatRhino, to drive increased adoption of AI for industrial usehttps://www.scmp.com/tech/big-tech/article/3227583/chinese-e-commerce-giant-jdcom-unveils-own-large-language-model-chatrhino-drive-increased-adoption?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.14 08:00;
;;

;中国电商巨头京东推出了自己的大语言模型（LLM） ) – 代表用于训练 ChatGPT 等聊天机器人的技术 – 预计该技术将加大该国大型科技公司将人工智能 (AI) 引入各种工业应用的力度。

;

;法学硕士的价值“将是周四，在北京举行的年度 JD Discovery 技术峰会上，5 月被任命为京东新任首席执行官的 Sandy Xu Ran 在该公司 ChatRhino 法学硕士揭幕仪式上说道。 ChatRhino中文名为“燕西”，在峰会上被描述为一种人工智能模型，结合了70%的通用数据和30%的原生智能供应链数据。据称，它提供了从零售和物流到金融和医疗保健等一系列行业的有针对性的解决方案。

;

;法学硕士是深度学习人工智能算法，可以使用非常大的数据来识别、总结、翻译、预测和生成内容

;

;“京东的大模型进化与我们对技术的不懈追求是一致的，”徐在技术峰会上表示。她表示，此举“标志着我们致力于利用技术造福行业和整个社会”。

;

;这家总部位于北京的公司进军人工智能模型，反映了中国科技行业缩小与人工智能领域差距的强烈兴趣。随着政府着手实施法学硕士国家标准，以配合监管人工智能的努力，西方国家正在构建类似 ChatGPT 的服务。

;

;在微软公司支持的初创公司 OpenAI 于 11 月推出 ChatGPT 后，中国大型科技公司竞相培育挑战者，北京将希望寄托在人工智能开发上，以推动工业生产力并推动全球第二大经济体在疫情后的增长。

;

;百度、阿里巴巴集团、腾讯今年早些时候，控股公司和华为技术有限公司推出了各自的法学硕士申请，以在各个行业得到更广泛的采用。阿里巴巴拥有《南华早报》。

;

;虽然京东的 LLM 培训于 2021 年开始，但公司高管在周四的峰会上透露，该公司决定不提前发布，以超越该技术处理随机数据的能力

;

;“我们需要使用大型[语言]模型来创造行业价值......而不是闲聊或画东西”，京东技术董事长曹鹏表示

;

;在峰会上预先录制的视频中，京东员工展示了公司如何使用 ChatRhino 自动化工具 AI Growth Marketing 将营销转化为营销只需几分钟即可通过自己的基于智能手机的网页将想法转变为成熟的活动。

;

;如果没有人工智能的帮助，相同的过程将需要长达两周的时间才能完成，并且需要营销人员、设计师和营销人员之间的密切合作京东员工表示。

;

;目前中国开发的人工智能模型有一半位于北京

;

;京东周四还推出了京医千寻，翻译为“问”医生千次”，这是公司京东健康部门基于ChatRhino的特定LLM。

;

;它通过快速迁移和学习各种医疗健康场景来自动部署产品和解决方案，京东预计将成为远程医疗服务的基础。

;

;北京目前是许多人工智能初创企业以及京东、百度和 TikTok 母公司字节跳动等大型科技公司的所在地。一半是中国培养的法学硕士。北京市经济和信息化局局长姜光智表示，在已开办的约 80 个法学硕士项目中，中国资本占了 40 个。

; Fri, 14 Jul 2023 08:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong’s urban search and rescue team sets sights on international accreditation after successful Turkey missionhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3227612/hong-kongs-urban-search-and-rescue-team-sets-sights-international-accreditation-after-successful?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.14 08:00;
;;

;香港消防队二月前往土耳其执行地震救援任务当局表示，将提高训练标准，以在三年内获得救援能力的国际认证

;

;消防处城市搜救队指挥官姚文扬周四表示，派出49名人员前往土耳其，旨在获得联合国咨询小组的认可。

;

;“我们的城市搜救队成立的目标是成为国际公认的‘中型’救援队，”耀说。 “事实证明，这次在土耳其的任务是一个良好的开始，并为我们的经验做出了贡献。”

;

;姚是代表前往土耳其的 49 名团队成员以及来自移民局和移民局的其他 10 名工作人员发言的。卫生和安全局因在为期 9 天的任务中在该国东南部哈塔伊省营救四人并打捞尸体而被授予首届行政长官模范表现奖。

;

;国际搜索救援咨询小组是联合国认可的机构，负责协调全球救援任务并为国家救援队制定搜救标准。

;

;它将认可的救援队分为“轻型”、“中型”和“重型”与他们的技术和医疗能力相一致。

;

;中型团队能够在现场维持长达 7 天的 24 小时作业，并有能力使用警犬、索具和吊装进行搜索。它还能够切割结构钢。

;

;团队还必须在模拟演习中通过对其结构、培训计划和性能的评估才能获得认证。

;

;派出的消防队员前往土耳其的是由 160 人组成的城市搜救队的成员，该队成立于 2009 年，负责在结构倒塌、山体滑坡和其他重大事件中执行救援任务。

;

;姚，同时也是消防和救护车部门的指挥官学院透露，目前为新队员进行的36小时最后训练将变得更加艰难，以提高在陌生环境中的能力，这也将模仿海外任务。

;

;香港队派往土耳其地震任务名为作为首个最高奖项获得者

;

;“明年我们会延长到72小时，并计划在大湾区的培训中心举行，这样可以更好地模拟我们会员的情况姚解释道。

;

;湾区是北京的倡议，旨在将香港、澳门和中国内地九个城市整合为一个经济强国。

;

;土耳其任务是城市搜救队自2009年成立以来的首次海外行动。2008年四川发生7.9级地震时，该市派出消防部门人员。

;

;土耳其的团队携带了 8 吨（8.8 吨）的设备，包括一架可以生成周围环境 3D 模型的无人机，以及具有超宽带雷达和声学功能的生命探测器，用于寻找心跳和呼吸迹象。

;

;行政长官李家超周四赞扬了该团队在执行任务期间的奉献精神、专业精神和对人道主义的承诺。

;

;该市领导人表示，该团队努力获得国际认证，这是努力的一部分加强香港的全球地位得到了北京的支持。

;

;他补充说，内地和香港救援人员之间的合作是“一个国家，两种制度”原则成功的明显标志。

;

;李说：“香港将加强与大湾区城市在防灾减灾救灾方面的合作。”

;

;加入香港应变队的两只搜救史宾格犬Umi和Twix，活动现场亦获殊荣，并与救援人员合影。

;

;香港消防英雄重温土耳其地震救援奇迹

;

;姚表示救援人员先检查环境无人机制作的 3D 模型，然后派出救援犬和生命探测器来定位受害者。

;

;团队成员、代理站员苏志安 (So Chi-on) 表示，他与同事分享了评估操作环境的安全技巧。

;

;“尽管我通常是一名训练官，但在执行任务期间，我和我的同事一样是一名救援人员。苏说：“安全是最重要的。”

;

;香港首位发现生还者的署理高级消防员梁志宏表示，队伍技能充足，但可以学习适应现场条件更好了。

;

;“我很紧张，因为我们从未见过或经历过如此巨大的灾难现场。我们预计会遇到很多挑战。”他说。

;

;但梁说，他通过代表城市和部门获得了使命感。

; Fri, 14 Jul 2023 08:20:02 +0800 Indonesians going into debt for Blackpink, Coldplay tickets shows dark side of fintech revolutionhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3227416/indonesians-going-debt-blackpink-coldplay-tickets-shows-dark-side-fintech-revolution?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.14 08:15;
;;

;去年11月中旬，7万人排队数小时购买前往博恩的门票Pink，受欢迎的女子乐队Blackpink于三月初在雅加达举行的世界巡回演唱会。英国乐队 Coldplay 最近在 Instagram 帖子中宣布，其即将于 11 月在雅加达举行的 Music of the Spheres 世界巡演的所有门票均已售罄。

;

;对于印度尼西亚的音乐爱好者来说，毫无疑问现在是享受国际音乐的好时机，不仅仅是因为 Blackpink 和 Coldplay 正在中国驻足。 MUC Consulting 的一份报告援引财政部的记录表明，近几个月音乐会活动的增加非常显着，有助于增加当地的娱乐税收入。

;

;一月和二月，音乐会观众数量创造了 28.85 万亿卢比（19 亿美元）的收入，高于去年同期的 23.6 万亿卢比。

;

;虽然这似乎值得庆祝，但彭博社的一份报告揭露了一些人如何当地人正在通过网上贷款来参加这些音乐会，这引起了该国金融监管机构的警惕。金融服务管理局警告印度尼西亚人不要仅仅为了购买音乐会门票而使用“先买后付”的服务。

;

;确实有理由担心。据彭博社报道，2023 年 5 月，该国通过数字平台的未偿还贷款总额为 51.5 万亿卢比，比一年前增长了 28%。

;

;监管机构还警告不要被虚假贷款应用程序诈骗。报告表明，掠夺性贷款应用程序在 Covid-19 大流行后蓬勃发展，剥削人们并利用他们的经济困难。

;

;金融科技和数字贷款应用程序的兴起使银行业务流程民主化，让人们更容易使用低收入群体获得贷款。不过，这种进步也有一个缺点：如此快速地获得资金可能会促进更鲁莽的支出和消费主义，这对于一个拥有大量年轻人口的国家来说是一个危险的前景。

;

;印度尼西亚 2.7 亿人口中，有一半以上是由年轻人组成的。年龄在 18 至 39 岁之间的人。他们的成功和生产力在很大程度上取决于他们的成功和生产力，因为他们被期望建设国家的未来。

;

;但这里唯一的问题不仅仅是年轻人可能试图挥霍他们的钱。印度尼西亚电子商务背后的深层故事讲述了一个充满矛盾的故事。即使在今天，印度尼西亚估计仍有 9000 万人没有银行账户，也无法使用传统的银行账户。

;

;为这些没有银行账户的人群提供服务是政府的首要任务。与此同时，为越来越多地面临金融科技风险的精通技术的年轻一代提供咨询也成为一种基本需求。

;

;利用中国的电子商务专业知识来建设印度尼西亚的数字经济

;

; h3>;

;与许多亚洲经济体一样，印度尼西亚目前正在努力应对前所未有的电子商务增长带来的快速变化。它是全球第 11 大电子商务市场，预计今年的收入将超过 448 亿美元，超过巴西。

;

;印度尼西亚的电子商务革命在很大程度上可以归功于据世界银行估计，其中产阶级人口迅速增长，达到近 5200 万人。因此，年轻的印度尼西亚人在一个重要方面不同于他们的父母和祖父母一代：他们拥有更多的可支配收入和更重要的数字存在。这两个因素都可以解释印度尼西亚作为亚洲音乐界主要中心的新兴影响力。

;

;根据联合国报告，音乐产业是印度尼西亚 16 个创意经济部门中增长最快的行业之一，因为它拥抱数字化。疫情期间，印度尼西亚成为 Spotify 东南亚最大的流媒体中心之一。超过 50% 的音乐行业从业者利用电子商务来扩大生产规模并扩大市场份额。

;

;该国其他行业也是如此。在互联网用户和零售电子商务销售额方面，印度尼西亚在 2021 年领先马来西亚、菲律宾、新加坡、泰国和越南等其他地区国家。

;

;不可否认，数字化已经简化和丰富了人们的生活。人们的生活在很多方面都受到了影响，但它也助长了“财富弹性”文化。如今，在网上炫耀财富已成为常态，并可能导致暴力犯罪。它还可能造成骚乱和公众强烈反对，特别是对于民选官员而言。三月份，《雅加达邮报》的一篇报道披露了印度尼西亚总统佐科·维多多如何敦促公务员不要在社交媒体上炫耀自己的财富。

;

;无论是炫耀新发现的财富还是人们购买音乐会门票，显然，金融科技和数字革命的社会、心理和文化影响是我们尚未完全理解的。有一点是肯定的：这不仅对印度尼西亚政府而且对整个发展中国家的政府来说都充满挑战。

;

;

; Fri, 14 Jul 2023 08:20:02 +0800 Lisa Marie Presley died from small bowel obstruction, coroner sayshttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3227627/lisa-marie-presley-died-small-bowel-obstruction-coroner-says?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.14 07:10;
;;

;当局周四表示，丽莎·玛丽·普雷斯利死于小肠梗阻。;

;根据洛杉矶县法医验尸官的记录，歌手、词曲作者兼猫王埃尔维斯·普雷斯利 (Elvis Presley) 的继承人于 1 月 12 日去世，享年 54 岁。

;

;尸检结果被裁定为自然原因。包含有关导致普雷斯利死亡的更多细节的报告尚未发布。

;

;普雷斯利在洛杉矶一家医院去世，护理人员接到紧急电话称，一名妇女患有心脏病，她被紧急送往医院。在家中被捕。

;

;当时没有任何迹象表明可能导致医疗问题的原因。

;

;1 月 22 日，她被埋葬在格雷斯兰 (Graceland) 的家中。她小时候和父亲住在一起，如今这里已成为博物馆、旅游景点和猫王粉丝的圣地。

;

;普雷斯利留下了三个女儿：34 岁的黛西·琼斯和六人组演员莱利·克奥和 15 岁的女儿两岁双胞胎 Harper 和 Finley Lockwood。

;

;儿子 Benjamin Keough 于 2020 年去世。

;

;在她去世后，一场重大的法律斗争似乎将立即展开。随之而来的是普雷斯利的遗产问题。

;

;在丽莎·玛丽去世后，普雷斯利家族为争夺猫王数百万美元的财产而展开斗争

;

;在她的葬礼四天后，她的母亲普里西拉·普雷斯利提交了法庭文件，对 2016 年的一份对丽莎·玛丽·普雷斯利 (Lisa Marie Presley) 生前信托的修正案，取消了普里西拉·普雷斯利 (Priscilla Presley) 和一位前业务经理的受托人身份，并用她的两个最大的孩子取代了他们。

;

;但普里西拉·普雷斯利 (Priscilla Presley) 和现在担任唯一受托人的莱莉·克奥 (Riley Keough) 同意了于五月达成和解。

;

;周三，莱莉·克奥凭借《黛西·琼斯与六人组》获得了她的第一个艾美奖提名，并获得了限定剧或电视电影最佳女主角奖。

; Fri, 14 Jul 2023 05:50:02 +0800 US Supreme Court’s affirmative action decision a nod to education’s need to evolve with the timeshttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3227485/us-supreme-courts-affirmative-action-decision-nod-educations-need-evolve-times?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.14 03:30;
;;

;University admission policies in the United States have evolved around the policy of affirmative action. Using criteria formulated to promote diversity and reduce discrimination, they give preferential treatment to candidates from disadvantaged groups, ranging from racial and ethnic minorities to women and those from low-income families.

;

;Its roots date back to 1961, when John F. Kennedy established the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity. In the following years, affirmative action became an important constituent of the university admissions process.

;

;The recent ruling by the Supreme Court upheld an argument that race cannot be factored into the admissions policy of colleges in the US, and that the University of North Carolina and Harvard University are in breach of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment to the US Constitution.

;

;The policy of affirmative action is controversial in some circles, and over the years has been the subject of much debate. Including this kind of preferential treatment in addition to examination results and school grades stands in contrast to countries whose university admissions policies are based primarily or entirely on exam results.

;

;In the case of Hong Kong, universities funded by the University Grants Committee have a cap of 20 per cent on places for non-local students at sub-degree, undergraduate and taught postgraduate levels.

;

;More than half are from the mainland and the rest from all around the world. Some local students might see this as a threat while others see it as adding a valuable international dimension, greater diversity and higher overall standards.

;

;The case that led to the Supreme Court striking down affirmative action was brought by Students for Fair Admissions. The advocacy group argues that affirmative action is not fair, necessary or constitutional.

;

;Arguments on the other side of the issue, however, state that affirmative action redresses discrimination that has historically been targeted against minority groups, many of whom end up segregated in the US public school system based on their race, ethnicity or socioeconomic status.

;

;A large number of US schools are underfunded and lack the resources required to meet the needs of their students or enable them to reach their full academic potential. Neither can they consistently prepare their brightest candidates for the academic challenges of entry to top-tier universities. Access to supplementary academic support, such as additional private tutoring to raise standardised test scores, is simply not an option.

;

;It appears as though there is a large part of the US populace that feels affirmative action in university admissions is unfair, particularly among Asian-Americans. Concerns around this issue have grown amid the rise of anti-Asian racism during the Covid-19 pandemic. Increased geopolitical tensions between the US and China are also contributing to growing unease among Asians in the US.

;

;TikTok is targeted in the US for being Chinese, not for its deeds

;

;In a survey of 5,000 US adults whose results were released last month, the Pew Research Centre found significant opposition to selective colleges and universities taking prospective students' racial and ethnic backgrounds into account when making admissions decisions. Half of the respondents disapproved of the policy while 33 per cent approved and 16 per cent were not sure.

;

;With university admissions back in the spotlight, certain universities' policy of legacy admissions – prioritising applicants on the basis of historic family relationships – is also coming under heavy scrutiny. Lawyers for Civil Rights – a Boston-based non-profit – has filed a federal complaint with the Department of Education's Office for Civil Rights against Harvard, alleging that the university's legacy admissions practice is a violation of the Civil Right Act and thus unfair.

;

;The outcome of this latest round of complaints and lawsuits will take time to become clear. One thing that is certain, however, is that the outcome of decisions made in terms of university admissions, whether holistic or based on grades alone, has a significant impact on the subsequent direction of the individual and their value and contribution to society.

;

;China's ethnic groups face end to affirmative action in education, taxes

;

;The Chinese government clearly understands this and has undertaken comprehensive reform across all levels of education as part of the education modernisation plan that was announced in 2019. Its objective is to promote innovation, creativity, critical thinking and align teaching methodology with technical development.

;

;Education needs to constantly evolve to remain relevant and meet the requirements of today's rapidly changing world. We need to equip people with the skill sets required to address common challenges we face as global citizens, reduce disparity and provide for all members of society.

;

; Fri, 14 Jul 2023 03:50:02 +0800 Wimbledon: just 6 women’s players have a female coach. The WTA tour is trying to serve up changehttps://www.scmp.com/sport/article/3227590/wimbledon-just-6-womens-players-have-female-coach-wta-tour-trying-serve-change?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.14 03:00;
;;

;On the day of the Wimbledon singles draw, Billie Jean King and other founding members of the women's professional tennis tour gathered 8km (5 miles) away at a London hotel to mark the 50th anniversary of a meeting that led to the formation of today's WTA.

;

;That long-ago moment was prompted by frustration at being paid far less in prize money than the sport's male athletes. For all the progress since in that area, there remains an aspect of tennis in which gender equity is nowhere near being achieved: coaching.

;

;Of the 128 women in the singles bracket at Wimbledon, which ends this weekend, just six work with a female coach – roughly 5 per cent. All the coaches for men were men.

;

;“Terrible. Extremely disappointing,” King, the International Tennis Hall of Fame member and rights advocate, said when asked about the scarcity of female coaches.

;

;“It's about society, absolutely. You have to see it to be it. So if you don't see a woman up there as a coach, it doesn't even cross your brain. How do we get the top players to hire them? We've got to solve the problem.”

;

;King and others in the sport consider that a reflection of the same sort of entrenched bias that has prevented women from advancing in all manner of other fields – and the WTA is making efforts to change that through an initiative that pairs aspiring coaches with established ones.

;

;Only 13 of the women ranked in the Top 200 have a female coach, according to the WTA; of those, four are the mother of the relevant player.

;

;Chong blames fatigue, heat as she falls just short again in Victoria Park

;

;“We're all about equality, and I'd like to see an equal amount of male and female coaches out there,” WTA chairman and CEO Steve Simon said in an interview. “To say, 'We should have all female coaches' isn't what we're looking for, either. … In a perfect world, we'd have balance.”

;

;That is why the WTA created the Coach Inclusion Program, which is in its first full year after a smaller pilot run in 2022. Ten applicants were chosen to take classes and be paired with veteran coaches.

;

;Five shadowed coaches and players at a tournament in Charleston, South Carolina, in April; others will get that opportunity at events in Montreal and Cincinnati in August. The WTA plans to expand the programme in 2024.

;

;“A lot of these women taking part have the same level of qualifications as a lot of the coaches that are out on tour, but they have no idea how to actually put themselves out there and break into it,” said Mike Anders, the programme's director.

;

;“A lot of what happens is that once you're in, coaches more or less recycle themselves. So a big part is the exposure – getting the right contacts as much as the right experience.”

;

;The idea is to add candidates to the WTA's regularly updated database of certified, eligible coaches that is part of its Player Zone, an online resource for athletes.

;

;At the moment, only 15 of the 186 active coaches are women. That is 8 per cent.

;

;“There just isn't enough options,” Simon said. “We need more females on that list.”

;

;Macau announces tennis tournament in December featuring Bencic, Fritz, Tiafoe

;

;Why aren't there more? One possible explanation mentioned by Simon, coaches and players was this: in general, the most likely path to coaching is being a former player, and women leaving the tour in their late 20s or early 30s might find it tougher to balance having children with travelling the world as a coach when they stop competing.

;

;“They have a family. They become mothers. It's easier for men to have a family when they're an ex-player. Look at me: I have one child who's six, one who's three, and another who's one-and-a-half,” said Flavia Pennetta, who retired soon after winning the 2015 US Open.

;

;“It's unthinkable that I could take the time to coach someone. Maybe, down the road, I could coach. But I couldn't completely dedicate myself to a player now.”

;

;One of the half-dozen women who coached a woman at Wimbledon this year, Pam Shriver, is a mum. For years, she did not necessarily want to coach – other than at her son's middle school.

;

;But Shriver, who is also a TV commentator, is surprised no one even approached her about it before she connected last year on a part-time basis with Donna Vekic, who travels regularly with another coach, Nick Horvat.

;

;“One of the things I reflect on,” said Shriver, who won 21 grand slam titles in doubles and reached No. 3 in singles, “is I realised that if I had been a male player with my background, my success as a player in singles and doubles, and then been broadcasting and observed tennis as much as I've observed as a broadcaster for the last few decades, I would have already been asked.

;

;“For sure, I would have been.”

;

;Chris Tontz, who coaches American Claire Liu and mentored a pair of coaches at Charleston, points to a dearth of women hired at the lower levels by clubs, academies and federations.

;

;Chong moves on, Wong shows fight but crashes out at Victoria Park

;

;“It's still a long road for women,” Tontz said. “All it would take is for someone to take a chance on them.”

;

;One of the coaches shadowing him in April, Iris Harris, was a talented teen who reached the junior doubles semi-finals at Wimbledon in 2003 but had her playing career derailed when she tore a knee ligament and groin muscle. She turned to coaching and now, at 38, is a teaching pro in Florida.

;

;Harris thinks female coaches are limited by a perception that women “can get a little too emotional”. She also hears that they don't make as good hitting partners as men – even though female players don't hit against men in competition.

;

;“Some of us,” Harris said, “have never been given a chance.”

;

;At its root, King and others say, this is not merely about women's tennis. Or tennis, even.

;

;A 2019 study by Fifa, soccer's international governing body, found that more than 13 million girls and women played organised soccer, but only 7 per cent of coaches worldwide were women.

;

;When the Women's World Cup begins next week, 20 countries will be coached by men, 12 by women. In the NWSL women's soccer league, eight clubs are coached by men, four by women. (The numbers tilt the other way in the WNBA basketball league: nine female coaches, three male coaches.)

;

;“I don't think no one wants to hire a woman. It's more that you just don't see as many of them, so you just kind of always gravitate towards hiring a male coach – and there's really no reason for it,” Wimbledon quarter-finalist Jessica Pegula said.

;

;Coleman Wong seeks 'psychological' tweaks after more Hong Kong tennis history

;

;And it's not limited to sports, of course.

;

;“I do wish there were more female coaches. I do wish there were more women involved in tennis. Running tournaments. Agents. Journalists,” 2017 US Open champion Sloane Stephens said. “It's about the business world, the regular world, the entire world.”

;

;Caty McNally, who reached the past two US Open women's doubles finals, is one of the rare women with a female coach.

;

;She has two coaches: Kevin O'Neill, who is on tour full-time, and her mother, Lynn Nabors McNally, who travels part-time.

;

;“My mum knows just as much about tennis, in my opinion, as a lot of men,” McNally said. “I would never label her as less qualified of a coach because she's a lady.”

;

;Women have led women to grand slam titles, including two in a span of 1½ months in 2017, when Anabel Medina Garrigues coached Jelena Ostapenko to a trophy at the French Open and Conchita Martinez helped Garbiñe Muguruza at Wimbledon.

;

;That did not turn out to be a watershed moment for female coaches.

;

;Nor was three-time major champion Andy Murray's hiring of Amelie Mauresmo as his coach in 2014.

;

;“It's strange. I'm probably surprised … there's not more female coaches across both tours,” Murray said.

;

; Fri, 14 Jul 2023 03:20:02 +0800 Bill that could close Hong Kong trade offices in US advances in Senatehttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/3227624/bill-could-close-hong-kong-trade-offices-us-advances-senate?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.14 03:08;
;;

;Legislation that could close Hong Kong's economic and trade offices in the US cleared a key Senate committee on Thursday, a crucial step on its path to becoming law.

;

;The bill, called the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Office (HKETO) Certification Act, would require the White House to “remove the extension of certain privileges, exemptions and immunities” to the offices if it decides that Hong Kong no longer enjoys a high degree of autonomy from Beijing.

;

;The bill – sponsored by senators Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican, and Jeff Merkley, an Oregon Democrat – was approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and is now expected to go to the full Senate for a vote. A similar version of the bill has been introduced in the House of Representatives.

;

;“HKETOs in the United States now serve as another mouthpiece that the Chinese Communist Party uses to obscure its long record of human rights abuses against Hongkongers and other groups that Beijing deems a threat,” Rubio and Merkley said.

;

;There are a 14 HKETOs outside mainland China; the three in the United States are in Washington, New York and San Francisco.

;

;The offices, which primarily carry out trade promotion and cultural diplomacy responsibilities, are not diplomatic missions because Hong Kong is not a sovereign state. But they do have some of the privileges and immunities of diplomatic missions granted in many countries.

;

;The Hong Kong offices in the US enjoy privileges that include the capacity to buy and sell property and immunity from legal action, search and every form of the judicial process “as is enjoyed by foreign governments”.

;

;They operate autonomously from Beijing's foreign missions except in the realm of consular affairs.

;

;Since the national security law was imposed on Hong Kong in 2020, US lawmakers have questioned whether the city remains sufficiently autonomous to justify having its own representation separate from Beijing's missions. At recent congressional hearings, Hong Kong activists have pushed for the offices' closure.

;

;US must do more to punish Hong Kong leaders who undermine freedoms, panel hears

;

;To become law, the bill must pass in the Senate and House, then be signed by President Joe Biden.

;

;Within 30 days of the law taking effect, the president will be required to explain to Congress why the city's offices in the US should retain or lose their diplomatic privileges. The offices would be required to close within 180 days if the president opts for decertification.

;

;If the president approves them, the offices can operate for another year or until the next certification required by the United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992, unless a joint resolution of disapproval is issued by the House or Senate.

;

;Under the law, any US government entity wanting to enter an agreement or partnership with an HKETO would have to wait 90 days after the president's certification to ensure that Congress issues no disapproval resolution.

;

;The Rubio-Merkley bill would require an annual recertification process for the offices to accompany the US State Department's annual certification of Hong Kong's semi-autonomous status, a review mandated by the 1992 act.

;

;That measure, which guides US policy towards Hong Kong, also says the city will continue to receive differential treatment unless “otherwise expressly provided by law or by executive order”.

;

;In July 2020, president Donald Trump issued an executive order determining that Hong Kong was no longer “sufficiently autonomous to justify differential treatment in relation to the People's Republic of China” and stated that it was US policy to suspend or eliminate such treatment for the city.

;

;The order, which Biden extended for another year earlier this week, suspended Hong Kong's preferential treatment under a number of statutes, but did not address the HKETOs.

;

;After the trade offices bill was introduced in February, Hong Kong authorities urged Washington to “stop maliciously interfering” in its internal affairs and “to respect the basic norms governing international relations”.

;

;This response came in the wake of Hong Kong's extensive efforts to promote its return to the global stage after three years of pandemic shutdown.

;

;In January, after pressure from advocacy groups, the Smithsonian's National Museum of Asian Art ended its partnership with the trade offices in the US.

;

;Representatives from US-based NGOs Committee for Freedom in Hong Kong Foundation and the Hong Kong Democracy Council welcomed the Senate committee's advancement of the bill.

;

;The committee also approved a bill authorising the administration to negotiate a tax agreement with Taipei that would offer residents in the US and Taiwan relief from double taxation.

;An Italian court has sparked widespread outrage after clearing a janitor who groped a girl on the grounds that he did it for “just a few seconds” and without “libidinous or lusty intent”.

;

;According to court documents, the girl said the man came behind her, put his hands in her underwear, and slightly lifted her in the air as she pulled up her trousers after walking up a staircase with a friend.

;

;The verdict has triggered an online protest, with thousands of social media users posting videos of themselves touching intimate body parts with the hashtag #10seconds to show how long a “palpata breve” (short grope) can be.

;

;A stopwatch runs for 10 seconds while people look into the camera and touch intimate areas of their bodies.

;

;The online campaign was started earlier this week by comedian and White Lotus actor Paolo Camilli, who said, fondling his chest in front of the camera: “If this is not harassment, what is?”

;

;His post was followed by one from influencer Chiara Ferragni.

;

;Victims of school violence demand change as 'Hakpok #MeToo' sweeps South Korea

;

;The incident took place in April last year in Rome at a high school in the Ostiense neighbourhood, and “the whole thing lasted about five to 10 seconds”, judges said in their ruling.

;

;The janitor, 66, said he reached for the back of the girl's trousers, holding her up for a few seconds, “as a joke”. Afterwards he pleaded with the girl to let it pass, telling her, “You will ruin my life, I didn't do anything to you.”

;

;In their verdict, dated July 6, a panel of judges concluded that the inappropriate gesture was so brief that it left “ample doubts” on whether it was voluntary, and found the argument that it was in jest “convincing”.

;

;Andrea Buitoni, a lawyer for the girl, told the Fanpage news site that the decision would “definitely” be appealed.

;

;“This is not the way an old man jokes with a 17-year-old girl. At least that's what I think,” the girl was quoted as saying by the Corriere della Sera newspaper, which said she has just turned 18.
